node.text: Frackers in America’s largest oil field are letting massive amounts of methane spill into the atmosphere. These scientists and activists are trying to find the leaks and get them plugged before they cook the planet further.

node.title: The Methane Hunters Racing to Change the Course of Global Warming

node.text:
Astra + Pfizer = ?
Moderna + Sinovac = ?

In some countries, people have received a mixture of Covid vaccines. Nicole Sy breaks down what that could mean for the world's vaccinated, and those still waiting on their first shot. (via @quicktake)

node.title: What Happens When You Mix Covid Vaccines?

node.text: Few people have lost as much money as quickly as Bill Hwang. In March, the previously unknown Wall Street whale and his family firm, Archegos, triggered losses of more than $20 billion in just two days. The result was one of the most spectacular implosions in modern financial history. (via @businessweek)

node.title: How Archegos Capital Cost Wall Street $20 Billion

node.text: Almost 30 years ago, an American court ruled that victims of the Ferdinand Marcos regime in the Philippines should be compensated — setting off one of the most ambitious and valuable treasure hunts of all time. (via @businessweek)

node.title: Where Did Marcos Hide His $10 Billion Fortune?

node.text:
China's growing ranks of rural entrepreneurs are getting rich peddling their produce on social media. 

One of the scene's stars is Jin Guowei, aka Brother Pomegranate — an internet sensation with 7.3 million followers and 300 million yuan ($46 million) of sales in 2020. (video via @quicktake)

node.title: Livestreaming Farmers Earn Millions From Fruit on China’s TikTok

node.text:
In almost every way measurable, millennials in the U.S. at 40 are doing worse financially than the generations that came before them.

Fewer millennials own homes than their parents did at their age. They have more debt — especially student debt. They simply aren’t as wealthy. 

Now, if predictions of a long, post-Covid economic boom are to be believed, this may be the last opportunity an entire generation has to build wealth before heading off into retirement.

node.title: Millennials Are Running Out of Time to Build Wealth to Retire

node.text: When employees at software company 10Pines want a raise, they pitch their co-workers, not their boss. Here's what happens when a firm uses "radical transparency" to attract and retain talent.

node.title: Would You Let Your Colleagues Decide Your Salary?

node.text:
While the "15-minute city" model promotes neighborhood-level urban planning, Sweden is pursuing a hyper-local twist: a scheme to redesign every street in the nation.

For more, read the report by @citylab: bloomberg.com/citylab/design

node.text:
Two of the world's wealthiest individuals will attempt to fly into space just nine days apart.

Here's how their space trips compare. (via @quicktake)

node.title: Billionaire Space Race: Branson vs. Bezos

node.text: The sudden cancellation of Ant Group’s IPO shocked investors, but Beijing's slapdown of Jack Ma was years in the making. And Alibaba and Ant aren't the only tech firms under scrutiny by Chinese regulators.

node.title: How China Lost Patience With Its Loudest Billionaire

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on August 24, 2021. May be an image of drink and text that says 'McDonald's halts sales of milkshakes in theU.K. Bloomberg'.

node.text:
McDonald’s just yanked milkshakes from all menus in the U.K. because of supply problems.

The fast-food chain is also experiencing shortages of bottled drinks, according to the AP.

The company said it's “working hard to return these items to the menu.” Tap the link in our bio to read more.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on August 24, 2021. May be an image of outdoors, tree and text.

node.text:
South Africa’s unemployment rate surged to the highest on a global list of 82 countries monitored by Bloomberg.

The jobless rate rose to 34.4% in the second quarter from 32.6% in the three months through March. And the numbers could get worse. Tap the link in our bio for more.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on August 24, 2021. May be an illustration of text that says 'Visa shelled out $150,000 for CryptoPunk digital avatar NFT Bloomberg'.

node.text:
Visa bought a digital avatar for $150,000 in a show of support for digital assets.

It purchased CryptoPunk #7610 — featuring a woman with clown-green eyes and “hot lipstick” — for 49.5 Ether.

Visa is one of several financial institutions in the past year to lend legitimacy to the crypto world, actions that have helped fuel Bitcoin's rise to nearly $65,000 in April. Tap the link in bio to read more.

📷: Photo from Visa Inc.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on August 24, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Cryptocurrencies are coming back from the brink. Here's why. wneiena wneyaus Sthareum ethereum ethereum ethereum ethereum Bloomberg'.

node.text:
After months of languishing in the doldrums, cryptocurrencies are surging.

On Monday, Bitcoin breached the $50,000 mark for the first time since May. Other coins — including Ethereum, Cardano’s ADA and Dogecoin — also edged higher.

Crypto’s latest swings are a sign that Bitcoin miners are back in business after a recent Chinese crackdown. At the same time, there is continued evidence of more mainstream acceptance. Tap the link in bio to read more about crypto's surge.

📷: Nawadoln Siributr/EyeEm

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on August 23, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Millionsof at-home Covid test results may go uncounted unted Bloomberg'.

node.text:
Two popular at-home Covid-19 tests were launched without a way for reporting results to health officials, potentially leaving many cases uncounted by authorities as the delta variant spreads around the U.S. 

How many of the products have been sold and used isn’t clear. But one thing that is clear is that with the relaxed guidelines many positive or negative tests — both crucial to track the pandemic — could go uncounted. Read more in our link in bio.

📷: Tom Pennington/Getty Images

buttons.text: Visit the COVID-19 Information Center for vaccine resources.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on August 23, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'Dol need a booster if got the J&J Covid vaccine? Bloomberg'.

node.text:
The short answer is yes. If you got a J&J shot, you’ll probably need a booster at some point.

Scientists are collecting more data to make the final call. Here’s what we know: All the vaccines used in America are still doing their job of preventing hospitalizations and deaths from Covid-19.

U.S. officials are planning to offer Pfizer and Moderna boosters eight months after the second shot based on evidence that effectiveness against infection wanes over time. The vaccines also don't appear quite as strong against the highly contagious delta variant as they were against earlier versions of the virus. Tap the link in our bio for more.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on August 23, 2021. May be an image of phone, screen and text that says '9:41 D QA Library 19/30MIN S 4/12HRS anFrancisco 58° In Đisnpt hulu Entertainment 10 R ๑ Apple Apple'siOS 15 reversal shows it's now actually listening tousers Bloomberg'.

node.text:
Apple isn’t particularly known for listening to consumers when making design decisions. Steve Jobs used to say that consumers don’t know what they want and trust Apple to make decisions for them.

The company has stuck to this approach throughout several controversial launches, from 2015's “butterfly” keyboards to the iOS 7 design. But things may finally be changing.

For iOS 15’s release this year, Apple planned to make some of the biggest changes ever to Safari on an iPhone. The fundamental shift: moving the address bar from the top of the screen to the bottom, erasing nearly 15 years of muscle memory. After mounting complaints from users, Apple reversed course, making the new design an option in Settings. That means users will be offered two distinct interfaces for a core app, a rarity in the iOS world. Read more at the link in bio.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on August 23, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'U.S. .regulators give full approval to Pfizer's Covid vaccine BoNTech COVID-1 19 Vaccine vial contains 5 doses preservathe of03 aoular use. Contains ĐÔag no FORE USE Discard hours Authorization after 77"F Emergency Use stored at2 to 25°C (35 and time: Bloomberg'.

node.text:
The U.S. Food and Drug Administration just gave full approval to the Pfizer-BioNTech Covid vaccine.

The official endorsement may help sway people who have been reluctant to receive a shot thus far.

More than 200 million Pfizer doses already have been administered in the U.S.—and hundreds of millions more worldwide—since emergency use began in December. Read more, via the link in our bio.

📷: Getty Images

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on August 23, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, fire, outdoors and text.

node.text:
Resorts are starting to wake up to the appeal of mind expansion.

A new breed of retreat is offering not only the lush surroundings, pleasant accommodations, and well-prepared food of high-end vacations but also the spiritual healing and metaphysical self-discovery of guided, plant-based psychedelic experiences.

Colloquially they’re called trips, though most practitioners prefer the term “journey.” Tap the link in our bio to read more.

📷: Silo Wellness

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on August 23, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'How China brought local Covid cases to zero in 33 days Bloomberg'.

node.text:
It’s been just over a month, and China has once again squelched Covid-19, bringing its local cases down to zero.

It was more difficult this time. The arrival of the more infectious delta variant has raised the stakes, and it’s unclear how long the victory will last. 

The China model shows what it takes to get Covid under control, and raises questions about whether other nations would be willing—or able—to follow the same draconian steps. Tap the link in bio to read more.

📷: AFP/Getty

buttons.text: Visit the COVID-19 Information Center for vaccine resources.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on August 23, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, sitting and text that says 'Thevacaed are worried and scientists don't have answers Bloomberg'.

node.text:
Vaccinated people appear to be getting the coronavirus at a surprisingly high rate. But exactly how often isn’t clear, nor is it certain how likely they are to spread the virus to others.

There’s a lack of scientific studies with concrete answers, leaving public policy makers and corporate executives to make plans based on fragmented information.

Still, some facts are well established at this point. When infected, vaccinated people are much less likely to need to go to the hospital, much less likely to need intubation and much less likely to die from the illness. 

Tap the link in bio to explore the knowns and unknowns of Covid science.

node.text: Frackers in America’s largest oil field are letting massive amounts of methane spill into the atmosphere. These scientists and activists are trying to find the leaks and get them plugged before they cook the planet further.
